Text: This war is a long, long war, and it requires steadfast determination and it requires a complete understanding that we not only chase down Al Qaida but we disrupt terrorist safe havens as well as people who could provide the terrorists with support.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: I want to extend for a minute, Senator. And I’m curious about something you said. You said, “It’s not when, but if.” You think it’s inevitable because the sense of security is a very basic thing with everybody in this country worried about their kids.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Well, the president and his experts have told America that it’s not a question of if; it’s a question of when. And I accept what the president has said. These terrorists are serious, they’re deadly, and they know nothing except trying to kill.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I understand that. That’s why I will never stop at anything to hunt down and kill the terrorists.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: But you heard the president just say to you that we’ve added money.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Folks, the test is not if you’ve added money; the test is that you’ve done everything possible to make America secure. He chose a tax cut for wealthy Americans over the things that I listed to you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, we’ll talk about the tax cut for middle class here in a minute. But yes, I’m worried. I’m worried. I’m worried about our country. And all I can tell you is every day I know that there’s people working overtime, doing the very best they can. And the reason I’m worried is because there’s a vicious enemy that has an ideology of hate.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And the way to defeat them long-term, by the way, is to spread freedom.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Liberty can change habits. And that’s what’s happening in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President, we’re going to turn to questions now on domestic policy. And we’re going to start with health issues.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: And the first question is for President Bush and it’s from John Horstman.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: HORSTMAN
Text: Mr. President, why did you block the reimportation of safer and inexpensive drugs from Canada which would have cut 40 to 60 percent off of the cost?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I haven’t yet. Just want to make sure they’re safe. When a drug comes in from Canada, I want to make sure it cures you and doesn’t kill you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And that’s why the FDA and that’s why the surgeon general are looking very carefully to make sure it can be done in a safe way. I’ve got an obligation to make sure our government does everything we can to protect you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And what my worry is is that, you know, it looks like it’s from Canada, and it might be from a third world.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And we’ve just got to make sure, before somebody thinks they’re buying a product, that it works. And that’s why we’re doing what we’re doing.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Now, it may very well be here in December you’ll hear me say, I think there’s a safe way to do it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: There are other ways to make sure drugs are cheaper. One is to speed up generic drugs to the marketplace, quicker. Pharmaceuticals were using loopholes to keep brand — brand drugs in place, and generics are much less expensive than brand drugs. And we’re doing just that.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Another is to pass — to get our seniors to sign up to these drug discount cards, and they’re working.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Wanda Blackmore I met here from Missouri, the first time she bought drugs with her drug discount card, she paid $1.14, I think it was, for about $10 worth of drugs.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: These cards make sense.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And, you know, in 2006 seniors are going to get prescription drug coverage for the first time in Medicare. Because I went to Washington to fix problems.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Medicare — the issue of Medicare used to be called “Mediscare.” People didn’t want to touch it for fear of getting hurt politically.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I wanted to get something done. I think our seniors deserve a modern medical system. And in 2006, our seniors will get prescription drug coverage.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Thank you for asking.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator, a minute and a half.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: John, you heard the president just say that he thought he might try to be for it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Four years ago, right here in this forum, he was asked the same question - Can’t people be able to import drugs from Canada? You know what he said? “I think that makes sense. I think that’s a good idea” — four years ago.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, the president said, “I’m not blocking that.” Ladies and gentlemen, the president just didn’t level with you right now again.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: He did block it, because we passed it in the United States Senate. We sent it over to the House, that you could import drugs. We took care of the safety issues.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: We’re not talking about third-world drugs. We’re talking about drugs made right here in the United States of America that have American brand names on them and American bottles. And we’re asking to be able to allow you to get them.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: The president blocked it. The president also took Medicare, which belongs to you. And he could have lowered the cost of Medicare and lowered your taxes and lowered the costs to seniors.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: You know what he did? He made it illegal, illegal for Medicare to do what the V.A. does, which is bulk purchase drugs so that you can lower the price and get them out to you lower.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: He put $139 billion of windfall profit into the pockets of the drug companies right out of your pockets. That’s the difference between us. The president sides with the power companies, the oil companies, the drug companies. And I’m fighting to let you get those drugs from Canada, and I’m fighting to let Medicare survive.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I’m fighting for the middle class. That is the difference.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: If they’re safe, they’re coming. I want to remind you that it wasn’t just my administration that made the decision on safety. President Clinton did the same thing, because we have an obligation to protect you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Now, he talks about Medicare. He’s been in the United States Senate 20 years. Show me one accomplishment toward Medicare that he accomplished.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I’ve been in Washington, D.C., three and a half years and led the Congress to reform Medicare so our seniors have got a modern health care system. That’s what leadership is all about.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Actually, Mr. President, in 1997 we fixed Medicare, and I was one of the people involved in it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: We not only fixed Medicare and took it way out into the future, we did something that you don’t know how to do: We balanced the budget. And we paid down the debt of our nation for two years in a row, and we created 23 million new jobs at the same time.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And it’s the president’s fiscal policies that have driven up the biggest deficits in American history. He’s added more debt to the debt of the United States in four years than all the way from George Washington to Ronald Reagan put together. Go figure.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: The next question is for Senator Kerry. And this comes from Norma-Jean Laurent.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: LAURENT
Text: Senator Kerry, you’ve stated your concern for the rising cost of health care, yet you chose a vice presidential candidate who has made millions of dollars successfully suing medical professionals. How do you reconcile this with the voters?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Very easily. John Edwards is the author of the Patients’ Bill of Rights. He wanted to give people rights. John Edwards and I support tort reform. We both believe that, as lawyers — I’m a lawyer, too. And I believe that we will be able to get a fix that has alluded everybody else because we know how to do it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: It’s in my health-care proposal. Go to johnkerry.com. You can pull it off of the Internet. And you’ll find a tort reform plan.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, ladies and gentlemen, important to understand, the president and his friends try to make a big deal out of it. Is it a problem? Yes, it’s a problem. Do we need to fix it, particularly for OGBYNs (sic) and for brain surgeons and others? Yes.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: But it’s less than 1 percent of the total cost of health care.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Your premiums are going up. You’ve gone up, in Missouri, about $3,500. You’ve gone up 64 percent. You’ve seen co-pays go up, deductibles go up. Everything’s gone up.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Five million people have lost their health insurance under this president. He’s done nothing about it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I have a plan. I have a plan to lower the cost of health care for you. I have a plan to cover all children. I have a plan to let you buy into the same health care senators and congressmen give themselves.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I have a plan that’s going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And I have a plan that will take the catastrophic cases out of the system, off your backs, pay for it out of a federal fund, which lowers the premiums for everybody in America, makes American business more competitive and makes health care more affordable.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, all of that can happen, but I have to ask you to do one thing - Join me in rolling back the president’s unaffordable tax cut for people earning more than $200,000 a year. That’s all.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Ninety-eight percent of America, I’m giving you a tax cut and I’m giving you health care.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President, a minute and a half.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Let me see where to start here.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: First, the National Journal named Senator Kennedy the most liberal senator of all. And that’s saying something in that bunch. You might say that took a lot of hard work.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: The reason I bring that up is because he’s proposed $2.2 trillion in new spending, and he says he going to tax the rich to close the tax gap.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: He can’t. He’s going to tax everybody here to fund his programs. That’s just reality.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And what are his health programs? First, he says he’s for medical liability reform, particularly for OB/GYNs. There’s a bill on the floor of the United States Senate that he could have showed up and voted for if he’s so much for it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Secondly, he says that medical liability costs only cause a 1 percent increase. That shows a lack of understanding. Doctors practice defensive medicine because of all the frivolous lawsuits that cost our government $28 billion a year.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And finally, he said he’s going to have a novel health care plan. You know what it is? The federal government is going to run it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: It’s the largest increase in federal government health care ever. And it fits with his philosophy. That’s why I told you about the award he won from the National Journal.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: That’s what liberals do. They create government-sponsored health care. Maybe you think that makes sense. I don’t.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Government-sponsored health care would lead to rationing. It would ruin the quality of health care in America.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, we got several questions along this line, and I’m just curious if you’d go further on what you talked about with tort reform. Would you be favoring capping awards on pain and suffering? Would you limit attorney’s fees?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: A follow-up…

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Yes. A follow-up on this for…

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Yes, I think we should look at the punitive and we should have some limitations.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: But look, what’s really important, Charlie, is the president is just trying to scare everybody here with throwing labels around. I mean, “compassionate conservative,” what does that mean? Cutting 500,000 kids from after-school programs, cutting 365,000 kids from health care, running up the biggest deficits in American history.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Mr. President, you’re batting 0 for 2.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I mean, seriously — labels don’t mean anything. What means something is: Do you have a plan? And I want to talk about my plan some more — I hope we can.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: We’ll get to that in just a minute.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Thirty seconds, President Bush.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: You’re right, what does matter is a plan. He said he’s for — you’re now for capping punitive damages?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: That’s odd. You should have shown up on the floor in the Senate and voted for it then.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Medical liability issues are a problem, a significant problem. He’s been in the United States Senate for 20 years and he hasn’t addressed it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: We passed it out of the House of Representatives. Guess where it’s stuck? It’s stuck in the Senate, because the trial lawyers won’t act on it. And he put a trial lawyer on the ticket.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: The next question is for President Bush, and it comes from Matthew O’Brien.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: O’BRIEN: Mr. President, you have enjoyed a Republican majority in the House and Senate for most of your presidency. In that time, you’ve not vetoed a single spending bill. Excluding $120 billion spent in Iran and — I’m sorry, Iraq and Afghanistan, there has been $700 billion spent and not paid for by taxes.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Please explain how the spending you have approved and not paid for is better for the American people than the spending proposed by your opponent.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Right, thank you for that.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: We have a deficit. We have a deficit because this country went into a recession. You might remember the stock market started to decline dramatically six months before I came to office, and then the bubble of the 1990s popped. And that cost us revenue. That cost us revenue.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Secondly, we’re at war. And I’m going to spend what it takes to win the war, more than just $120 billion for Iraq and Afghanistan. We’ve got to pay our troops more. We have. We’ve increased money for ammunition and weapons and pay and homeland security.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I just told this lady over here we spent — went from $10 billion to $30 billion to protect the homeland. I think we have an obligation to spend that kind of money.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And plus, we cut taxes for everybody. Everybody got tax relief, so that they get out of the recession.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I think if you raise taxes during a recession, you head to depression. I come from the school of thought that says when people have more money in their pocket during economic times, it increases demand or investment. Small businesses begin to grow, and jobs are added.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: We found out today that over the past 13 months, we’ve added 1.9 million new jobs in the last 13 months.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I proposed a plan, detailed budget, that shows us cutting the deficit in half by five years.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And you’re right, I haven’t vetoed any spending bills, because we work together.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Non-homeland, non-defense discretionary spending was raising at 15 percent a year when I got into office. And today it’s less than 1 percent, because we’re working together to try to bring this deficit under control.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Like you, I’m concerned about the deficit. But I am not going to shortchange our troops in harm’s way. And I’m not going to run up taxes, which will cost this economy jobs.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Thank you for your question.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, a minute and a half.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Let me begin by saying that my health-care plan is not what the president described. It is not a government takeover.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: You have choice. Choose your doctor, choose your plan. The government has nothing to do with it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: In fact, it doesn’t ask you to do anything — if you don’t want to take it, you don’t have to. If you like your high premiums, you keep them. That’s the way we leave it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now with respect to the deficit, the president was handed a $5.6 trillion surplus, ladies and gentlemen. That’s where he was when he came into office.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: We now have a $2.6 trillion deficit. This is the biggest turnaround in the history of the country. He’s the first president in 72 years to lose jobs.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: He talked about war. This is the first time the United States of America has ever had a tax cut when we’re at war.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, others, knew how to lead. They knew how to ask the American people for the right things.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: One percent of America, the highest one percent of income earners in America, got $89 billion of tax cut last year. One percent of America got more than the 80 percent of America that earned from $100,000 down.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: The president thinks it’s more important to fight for that top 1 percent than to fight for fiscal responsibility and to fight for you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I want to put money in your pocket. I am — I have a proposal for a tax cut for all people earning less than the $200,000. The only people affected by my plan are the top income earners of America.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: I both — I heard you both say — I have heard you both say during the campaign, I just heard you say it, that you’re going to cut the deficit by a half in four years. But I didn’t hear one thing in the last three and a half minutes that would indicate how either one of you do that.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, look at the budget. One is make sure Congress doesn’t overspend.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: But let me talk back about where we’ve been. The stock market was declining six months prior to my arrival.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: It was the largest stock market correction — one of the largest in history, which foretold a recession.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Because we cut taxes on everybody — remember, we ran up the child credit by $1,000, we reduced the marriage penalty, we created a 10 percent bracket, everybody who pays taxes got relief — the recession was one of the shortest in our nation’s history.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, 30 seconds.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: After 9/11, after the recession had ended, the president asked for another tax cut and promised 5.6 million jobs would be created. He lost 1.6 million, ladies and gentlemen. And most of that tax cut went to the wealthiest people in the country.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: He came and asked for a tax cut — we wanted a tax cut to kick the economy into gear. Do you know what he presented us with? A $25 billion giveaway to the biggest corporations in America, including a $254 million refund check to Enron.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Wrong priorities. You are my priority.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, the next question will be for you, and it comes from James Varner, who I believe is in this section.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. Varner? You need a microphone.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: VARNER
Text: Thank you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: VARNER
Text: Senator Kerry, would you be willing to look directly into the camera and, using simple and unequivocal language, give the American people your solemn pledge not to sign any legislation that will increase the tax burden on families earning less than $200,000 a year during your first term?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Absolutely. Yes. Right into the camera. Yes. I am not going to raise taxes.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I have a tax cut. And here’s my tax cut.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I raise the child-care credit by $1,000 for families to help them be able to take care of their kids.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I have a $4,000 tuition tax credit that goes to parents — and kids, if they’re earning for themselves — to be able to pay for college.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And I lower the cost of health care in the way that I described to you.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Every part of my program I’ve shown how I’m going to pay for it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And I’ve gotten good people, like former Secretary of the Treasury Bob Rubin, for instance, who showed how to balance budgets and give you a good economy, to help me crunch these numbers and make them work.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I’ve even scaled back some of my favorite programs already, like the child-care program I wanted to fund and the national service program, because the president’s deficit keeps growing and I’ve said as a pledge, “I’m going to cut the deficit in half in four years.”

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, I’m going to restore what we did in the 1990s, ladies and gentlemen: pay as you go. We’re going to do it like you do it. The president broke the pay-as-you-go rule.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Somebody here asked the question about, “Why haven’t you vetoed something?” It’s a good question. If you care about it, why don’t you veto it?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I think John McCain called the energy bill the “No Lobbyist Left Behind” bill.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I mean, you’ve got to stand up and fight somewhere, folks.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I’m pledging I will not raise taxes; I’m giving a tax cut to the people earning less than $200,000 a year.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, for the people earning more than $200,000 a year, you’re going to see a rollback to the level we were at with Bill Clinton, when people made a lot of money.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And looking around here, at this group here, I suspect there are only three people here who are going to be affected - the president, me, and, Charlie, I’m sorry, you too.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President, 90 seconds.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: He’s just not credible when he talks about being fiscally conservative. He’s just not credible. If you look at his record in the Senate, he voted to break the caps — the spending caps — over 200 times.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And here he says he’s going to be a fiscal conservative, all of a sudden. It’s just not credible. You cannot believe it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And of course he’s going to raise your taxes. You see, he’s proposed $2.2 trillion of new spending. And you say: Well, how are you going to pay for it? He says, well, he’s going to raise the taxes on the rich — that’s what he said — the top two brackets. That raises, he says $800 billion; we say $600 billion.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: We’ve got battling green eye shades.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Somewhere in between those numbers — and so there’s a difference, what he’s promised and what he can raise.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Now, either he’s going to break all these wonderful promises he’s told you about or he’s going to raise taxes. And I suspect, given his record, he’s going to raise taxes.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Is my time up yet?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: No, you can keep going.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Good. You looked at me like my clock was up.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I think that the way to grow this economy is to keep taxes low, is have an energy plan, is to have litigation reform. As I told you, we’ve just got a report that said over the past 13 months, we’ve created 1.9 million new jobs. Weâ€™re growing.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And so the fundamental question of this campaign is - Who’s going to keep the economy growing so people can work? That’s the fundamental question.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: I’m going to come back one more time to how these numbers add up and how you can cut that deficit in half in four years, given what you’ve both said.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Well, first of all, the president’s figures of $2.2 trillion just aren’t accurate. Those are the fuzzy math figures put together by some group that works for the campaign. That’s not the number.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Number two, John McCain and I have a proposal, jointly, for a commission that closes corporate giveaway loopholes. We’ve got $40 billion going to Bermuda. We’ve got all kinds of giveaways. We ought to be shutting those down.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And third, credible - Ladies and gentlemen, in 1985, I was one of the first Democrats to move to balance the budget. I voted for the balanced budget in ’93 and ’97. We did it. We did it. And I was there.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Thirty seconds. I’m sorry, thirty seconds, Mr. President.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Yes, I mean, he’s got a record. It’s been there for 20 years. You can run, but you can’t hide. He voted 98 times to raise taxes. I mean, these aren’t make-up figures.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And so people are going to have to look at the record. Look at the record of the man running for the president.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: They don’t name him the most liberal in the United States Senate because he hasn’t shown up to many meetings. They named him because of his votes. And it’s reality.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: It’s just not credible to say he’s going to keep taxes down and balance budgets.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President, the next question is for you, and it comes from James Hubb over here.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: HUBB
Text: Mr. President, how would you rate yourself as an environmentalist? What specifically has your administration done to improve the condition of our nation’s air and water supply?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Off-road diesel engines — we have reached an agreement to reduce pollution from off-road diesel engines by 90 percent.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I’ve got a plan to increase the wetlands by 3 million. We’ve got an aggressive brown field program to refurbish inner-city sore spots to useful pieces of property.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I proposed to the United States Congress a Clear Skies Initiative to reduce sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and mercury by 70 percent.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I have — was fought for a very strong title in the farm bill for the conservation reserve program to set aside millions of acres of land to help improve wildlife and the habitat.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: We proposed and passed a healthy forest bill which was essential to working with — particularly in Western states — to make sure that our forests were protected.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: What happens in those forests, because of lousy federal policy, is they grow to be — they are not — they’re not harvested. They’re not taken care of. And as a result, they’re like tinderboxes.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And over the last summers I’ve flown over there. And so, this is a reasonable policy to protect old stands of trees and at the same time make sure our forests aren’t vulnerable to the forest fires that have destroyed acres after acres in the West.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: We’ve got a good, common-sense policy.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Now, I’m going to tell you what I really think is going to happen over time is technology is going to change the way we live for the good for the environment.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: That’s why I proposed a hydrogen automobile — hydrogen-generated automobile. We’re spending $1 billion to come up with the technologies to do that.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: That’s why I’m a big proponent of clean coal technology, to make sure we can use coal but in a clean way.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I guess you’d say I’m a good steward of the land.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: The quality of the air’s cleaner since I’ve been the president. Fewer water complaints since I’ve been the president. More land being restored since I’ve been the president.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Thank you for your question.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, minute and a half.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Boy, to listen to that — the president, I don’t think, is living in a world of reality with respect to the environment.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, if you’re a Red Sox fan, that’s OK. But if you’re a president, it’s not.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Let me just say to you, number one, don’t throw the labels around. Labels don’t mean anything.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I supported welfare reform. I led the fight to put 100,000 cops on the streets of America. I’ve been for faith-based initiatives helping to intervene in the lives of young children for years. I was — broke with my party in 1985, one of the first three Democrats to fight for a balanced budget when it was heresy.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Labels don’t fit, ladies and gentlemen.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, when it comes to the issue of the environment, this is one of the worst administrations in modern history.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: The Clear Skies bill that he just talked about, it’s one of those Orwellian names you pull out of the sky, slap it onto something, like “No Child Left Behind” but you leave millions of children behind. Here they’re leaving the skies and the environment behind.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: If they just left the Clean Air Act all alone the way it is today, no change, the air would be cleaner than it is if you pass the Clear Skies act. We’re going backwards.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: In fact, his environmental enforcement chief air-quality person at the EPA resigned in protest over what they’re doing to what they are calling the new source performance standards for air quality.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: They’re going backwards on the definition for wetlands. They’re going backwards on the water quality.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: They pulled out of the global warming, declared it dead, didn’t even accept the science.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I’m going to be a president who believes in science.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Well, had we joined the Kyoto treaty, which I guess he’s referring to, it would have cost America a lot of jobs.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: It’s one of these deals where, in order to be popular in the halls of Europe, you sign a treaty. But I thought it would cost a lot — I think there’s a better way to do it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And I just told you the facts, sir. The quality of the air is cleaner since I’ve been the president of the United States. And we’ll continue to spend money on research and development, because I truly believe that’s the way to get from how we live today to being able to live a standard of living that we’re accustomed to and being able to protect our environment better, the use of technologies.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, 30 seconds.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: The fact is that the Kyoto treaty was flawed. I was in Kyoto, and I was part of that. I know what happened. But this president didn’t try to fix it. He just declared it dead, ladies and gentlemen, and we walked away from the work of 160 nations over 10 years.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: You wonder, Nikki, why it is that people don’t like us in some parts of the world. You just say: Hey, we don’t agree with you. Goodbye.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: The president’s done nothing to try to fix it. I will.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, the next question is for you. It involves jobs, which is a topic of the news today.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: And for the question, we’re going to turn to Jane Barrow.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BARROW
Text: Senator Kerry, how can the U.S. be competitive in manufacturing given — in manufacturing, excuse me — given the wage necessary and comfortably accepted for American workers to maintain the standard of living that they expect?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Jane, there are a lot of ways to be competitive. And unfortunately again I regret this administration has not seized them and embraced them. Let me give you an example.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: There is a tax loophole right now. If you’re a company in St. Louis working, trying to make jobs here, there is actually an incentive for you to go away. You get more money, you keep more of your taxes by going abroad.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I’m going to shut that loophole, and I’m going to give the tax benefit to the companies that stay here in America to help make them more competitive.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Secondly, we’re going to create a manufacturing jobs credit and a new jobs credit for people to be able to help hire and be more competitive here in America.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Third, what’s really hurting American business more than anything else is the cost of health care.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Now, you didn’t hear any plan from the president, because he doesn’t have a plan to lower the cost of health care.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Five million Americans have lost their health care; 620,000 Missourians have no health care at all; 96,000 Missourians have lost their health care under President Bush.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I have a plan to cover those folks. And it’s a plan that lowers cost for everybody, covers all children. And the way I pay for it — I’m not fiscally irresponsible — is I roll back the tax cut this president so fiercely wants to defend, the one for him and me and Charlie.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: I think you ought to get the break. I want to lower your cost to health care. I want to fully fund education, No Child Left Behind, special-needs education. And that’s how we’re going to be more competitive, by making sure our kids are graduating from school and college.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: China and India are graduating more graduates in technology and science than we are.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: We’ve got to create the products of the future. That’s why I have a plan for energy independence within 10 years.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And we’re going to put our laboratories and our colleges and our universities to work. And we’re going to get the great entrepreneurial spirit of this country, and we’re going to free ourselves from this dependency on Mideast oil.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: That’s how you create jobs and become competitive.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Mr. President, minute and a half.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Let me start with how to control the cost of health care: medical liability reform, for starters, which he’s opposed.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Secondly, allow small businesses to pool together so they can share risk and buy insurance at the same discounts big businesses get to do.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Thirdly, spread what’s called health savings accounts. It’s good for small businesses, good for owners. You own your own account. You can save tax-free. You get a catastrophic plan to help you on it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: This is different from saying, “OK, let me incent you to go on the government.”

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: He’s talking about his plan to keep jobs here. You know he calls it an outsourcing to keep — stop outsourcing. Robert Rubin looked at his plan and said it won’t work.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: The best way to keep jobs here in America is, one, have an energy plan. I proposed one to the Congress two years ago, encourages conservation, encourages technology to explore for environmentally friendly ways for coal — to use coal and gas. It encourages the use of renewables like ethanol and biodiesel.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: It’s stuck in the Senate. He and his running-mate didn’t show up to vote when they could have got it going in the Senate.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Less regulations if we want jobs here; legal reform if we want jobs here; and we’ve got to keep taxes low.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Now, he says he’s only going to tax the rich. Do you realize, 900,000 small businesses will be taxed under his plan because most small businesses are Subchapter S corps or limited partnerships, and they pay tax at the individual income tax level.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And so when you’re running up the taxes like that, you’re taxing job creators, and that’s not how you keep jobs here.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator, I want to extend for a minute, you talk about tax credits to stop outsourcing. But when you have IBM documents that I saw recently where you can hire a programmer for $12 in China, $56 an hour here, tax credits won’t cut it.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: You can’t stop all outsourcing, Charlie. I’ve never promised that. I’m not going to, because that would be pandering. You can’t.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: But what you can do is create a fair playing field, and that’s what I’m talking about.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: But let me just address what the president just said.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Ladies and gentlemen, that’s just not true what he said. The Wall Street Journal said 96 percent of small businesses are not affected at all by my plan.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: And you know why he gets that count? The president got $84 from a timber company that owns, and he’s counted as a small business. Dick Cheney’s counted as a small business. That’s how they do things. That’s just not right.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I own a timber company?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: That’s news to me.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Need some wood?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Most small businesses are Subchapter S corps. They just are.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I met Grant Milliron, Mansfield, Ohio. He’s creating jobs. Most small businesses — 70 percent of the new jobs in America are created by small businesses.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Taxes are going up when you run up the top two brackets. It’s a fact.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: President Bush, the next question is for you, and it comes from Rob Fowler, who I believe is over in this area.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: FOWLER
Text: President Bush, 45 days after 9/11, Congress passed the Patriot Act, which takes away checks on law enforcement and weakens American citizens’ rights and freedoms, especially Fourth Amendment rights.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: FOWLER
Text: With expansions to the Patriot Act and Patriot Act II, my question to you is, why are my rights being watered down and my citizens’ around me? And what are the specific justifications for these reforms?

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I appreciate that.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: I really don’t think your rights are being watered down. As a matter of fact, I wouldn’t support it if I thought that.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Every action being taken against terrorists requires court order, requires scrutiny.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: As a matter of fact, the tools now given to the terrorist fighters are the same tools that we’ve been using against drug dealers and white-collar criminals.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: So I really don’t think so. I hope you don’t think that. I mean, I — because I think whoever is the president must guard your liberties, must not erode your rights in America.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: The Patriot Act is necessary, for example, because parts of the FBI couldn’t talk to each other. The intelligence-gathering and the law-enforcement arms of the FBI just couldn’t share intelligence under the old law. And that didn’t make any sense.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: Our law enforcement must have every tool necessary to find and disrupt terrorists at home and abroad before they hurt us again. That’s the task of the 21st century.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And so, I don’t think the Patriot Act abridges your rights at all.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: BUSH
Text: And I know it’s necessary. I can remember being in upstate New York talking to FBI agents that helped bust a Lackawanna cell up there. And they told me they could not have performed their duty, the duty we all expect of them, if they did not have the ability to communicate with each other under the Patriot Act.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: GIBSON
Text: Senator Kerry, a minute and a half.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Former Governor Racicot, as chairman of the Republican Party, said he thought that the Patriot Act has to be changed and fixed.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: Congressman Jim Sensenbrenner, he is the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said over his dead body before it gets renewed without being thoroughly rechecked.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
Participants: GEORGE W. BUSHPRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES U.S. SENATOR JOHN F. KERRY (MA)DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
Speaker: KERRY
Text: A whole bunch of folks in America are concerned about the way the Patriot Act has been applied. In fact, the inspector general of the Justice Department found that John Ashcroft had twice applied it in ways that were inappropriate.

Title: October 8, 2004 Debate Transcript
